p: Previous studies revealed that orchids can be a potent source of anticancer agents. For instance, D. nobile showed cytotoxicity against human lung carcinoma, human ovary adenocarcinoma, and human promyelocytic leukemia cell lines [ 50, 51]. D. signatum exhibited cytotoxic activities against human MDA-23 1, HepG2, and HT-29 cancer cell lines [ 52]. D. chrysanthum inhibited the proliferation of leukemia HL-60 cells [ 11]. D. longicornu and D. moniliforme showed cytotoxic activities against HeLa and U251 cancer cell lines [ 4, 5, 35]. Bulbophyllum kwangtungense showed antitumor activities against HeLa and K562 human tumor cell lines [ 53] while Bulbophyllum odoratissimum was found to have cytotoxic activities against human cancer cell lines, such as human leukemia cell lines K562 and HL-60, human hepatoma BEL-7402, human lung adenocarcinoma A549, and human stomach cancer cell line SGC-7901 [ 54]. Prior to this study, no comparative investigation of the cytotoxic activity of plants grown in vitro versus wild plants has been reported.
